journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Stereoscopic particle image velocimetry of the flow field in the rotor exit region of a forward-blade centrifugal turbomachine

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, 424 Hafez Avenue, Tehran 15514, Iran. email: mntzrn@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: This article reports the measurements of the complicated flow phenomena in the rotor exit region of a multi-blade centrifugal fan with stereoscopic particle image velocimetry (PIV). The main purpose is to enhance the quality of raw PIV data for future turbulence analyses. The instantaneous and averaged quantities are sensitive to phase-matching of the raw data since the blade-to-blade distance is short. An image processing based procedure is devised that identifies the rotor margin and blade tips location and selects the phase-resolved images. The large measurement area is divided into four fields of view. PIV data post-processing optimizes the relative position of different fields of view and enhances matching between them by detecting the phase-resolved images. The accuracy and reliability of measurements are examined by error and convergency analyses. The results are used to analyse the interactions between jet and wake structures as well as between rotor exit flow and the volute stream near the rotor. Jet/wake structures, non-uniform flow patterns, and high vorticity layers with opposite value in both sides of each blade are novel measured patterns in centrifugal fan which also occur in other centrifugal turbomachines. Such data are a necessary prerequisite for the accurate turbulence modelling of the complicated jet/wake flow and the mixing in the volute.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Flow structure in turbomachines is complicated, three-dimensional (3D), and unsteady. These complexities originate from intensive interactions of phase-dependent flow structures with moving or stationary parts of the turbomachine. Transient wakes, flow separations, high deformations, acoustic noise, vibration of various components, and flow non-uniformities are a few of the consequences of these interactions that significantly affect the efficiency and performance of a turbomachine. A detailed investigation of the flow field plus modifications in the geometry and/or operating condition can resolve these deficiencies. Experimental research identifies different phenomena in the flow field and can improve turbulence modelling and enhance flow predictions.

Some experimental studies on flow field interactions in turbomachines have used single-point measurements and spatial variation of quantities is extracted by measuring the flow properties at various locations [1–3]. Although covering a region with sufficient resolution for the analysis of turbulent structures is a desired target, traversing a measuring probe accompanies uncertainties, which are important in small scales. Particle image velocimetry (PIV) has the benefit that it captures spatial instantaneous flow field which helps the study of flow structures in extensive detail. It enables researchers to extract different turbulent terms and have insight into the various mechanisms of interaction between turbulent structures. It is now possible to measure the definitions that were already known for a long time, e.g. vorticity, strain, etc. and investigate their local and combined effects.

Previous research has identified the structure of flow field and turbulence characteristics in selected turbomachines using PIV. Both two-component PIV (2C-PIV) and three-component PIV (3C-PIV) have been employed. Among different components, rotor operation has a significant impact on its downstream, such as stator blades and casing. According to Sanders et al. [4], chopping of rotor wake structures by stator blades of an axial compressor generates counter-rotating vortices on both sides of each chopped wake segment. This phenomenon is a source of unsteadiness downstream of the rotor blades. Similar flow patterns have also been observed in the experimental works of Chow et al. [5] and Uzol et al. [6] on a multi-stage axial turbomachine. It is stated that the most influential contributors to the complex flow of this type of turbomachine are wake–wake and wake–blade interactions [5]. The wakes generated by rotor and stator blades are characterized by high turbulent kinetic energy, elevated deformations, and vortical flow structures. The interaction between rotor and stator wakes generates localized spots with high level of turbulent kinetic energy and concentrated vorticity. This phenomenon causes discontinuities in the wake trajectories. Although these localized spots diffuse as advected downstream towards the second stage of the turbomachine, their turbulence intensity is still higher than that in adjacent regions and significantly affects the flow field. Non-uniformities and unsteadiness due to the rotation of the rotor cause phase-dependent variations in the flow field, which in turn generate high deterministic stresses [6].

Analysis of turbulence characteristics in the tip and hub regions of an axial turbomachine has revealed that the tip vortices are also a dominant source of unsteadiness and deterministic stress in flow structure [7]. Experimental measurements show that the level of deterministic kinetic energy along tip vortex trajectories is much larger than the corresponding value at mid-span and hub. The turbomachinery flow is even more complex at off-design condition. It is reported at near-stall condition that the tip leakage vortices break down earlier than at design point and interact more severely with the main flow [8]. This causes more flow blockages and greater losses of energy.

Flow field of centrifugal turbomachines contains some similar flow characteristics compared with that of axial turbomachines. Existence of jet/wake patterns from rotor blades and diffuser vanes, interactions among them, as well as among these structures and solid components and separation of the flow are the most prominent contributors in the flow of a centrifugal turbomachine [9, 10]. Additionally, there is often a volute with variable cross-section that collects jets and wakes, mixes them with the flow from previous circumferential locations, and finally delivers the fluid to the outlet cross-section. Phase dependency is another common characteristic among axial and centrifugal turbomachines that generates considerable cyclic flow variations and deterministic stress [11]. Experimental investigation of flow field within the rotor blades of a centrifugal pump has indicated that at the design condition, the flow is well-behaved and blade congruent [12]. On the contrary, the flow field at off-design condition contains separation and vortical structures that significantly affect turbomachine performance and efficiency. Additionally, the existence of recirculation zones within the blade passages at stalled condition creates backflow along the blade pressure side.

Multi-blade forward-curved centrifugal fans, in comparison with centrifugal pumps and compressors, have a larger rotor exit-to-inlet area ratio and a larger number of rotor blades. Consequently, flow structures are more 3D and the interaction between jet–wake structures can be stronger due to a smaller blade-to-blade distance. The jet–wake pattern at the rotor exit of centrifugal fans was observed in various experimental studies [13–15]. One undesirable and complicating phenomenon in the multi-blade centrifugal fans is the existence of a large separation zone near the inlet shroud [13, 14, 16]. This separation zone decreases the active rotor flow area and significantly reduces the performance of the turbomachine. A smaller separation zone has less noise and more uniform blade loading [17]. Axial variation in flow field along the rotor axis and tangential pressure gradient around the rotor create circumferential variations in flowrate and separation zone size, and are other contributors to poor machine performance and efficiency [14].

Various experimental studies have enhanced the efficiency of multi-blade centrifugal fans [13, 16–18]. Based on 2C-PIV measurements of velocity between impeller and diffuser of a vaned centrifugal fan, extension of separated flow from the hub into the volute and generation of a high vertical zone have a significant role in complicating the flow field, particularly near the cut-off region [19]. The non-uniformity of discharge flow from the impeller was interpreted as a result of secondary flow extension in turbomachine. Stereoscopic particle image velocimetry (SPIV) measurements of flow in various sections (inside and outside the rotor) of multi-blade centrifugal fan have indicated that in comparison with rotor inside zone, the flow field at the outside zone of the rotor is significantly more non-uniform and complex [20]. Flow separation and wakes at the suction side of the blades as well as the shroud-induced separation are the most important reasons for complex flow patterns at the exit region of the rotor. SPIV measurements on the rotor exit flow field are obtained in the absence of casing to remove the optical obstructions and undesirable effect of light refraction through the casing [20]. However, flow confinement inside the volute increases jet–wake interactions at the outside zone of the rotor and its elimination causes a different flow field. Both studies have only reported average velocities and no turbulence analysis are mentioned. More optimizations require detailed spatial and temporal investigations of the flow field. Although a vast range of studies have been performed in the field of temporal investigation of flow in centrifugal fans, experimental studies on the structure and spatial analysis of flow field in this device are scarce.

Such measurements are also beneficial for flow and turbulence modelling in centrifugal turbomachines. Accurate turbulence modelling is the most critical part of a reliable flow field prediction. Since the flow in a turbomachine is highly turbulent, unsteady, 3D, and anisotropic, the deviation of the modelled turbulent stresses from real stresses may become significant in some regions [11, 21]. The first step in enhancement of a turbulence model is a detailed investigation of flow field and turbulence characteristics, which is the main objective of this research.

The intention here is to measure the flow field in the rotor exit region of a squirrel-cage fan, which is a popular forward-curved blade centrifugal type. The reasons behind this selection are given as follows.
Flat side walls and long blades make squirrel-cage fan an ideal test ground for the study of interaction between jet and wake structures and the flow in a curved channel which is also the principal configuration in any centrifugal turbomachine.
There is a lack of detailed analysis of the complex 3D flow field in the multi-blade centrifugal fan in the literature.
Squirrel-cage fans have many applications in ventilation and air-conditioning systems since they have low noise and are simple to manufacture. However, this type of turbomachine requires optimization for its low performance and efficiency.
There was a long history of research and optimization on this fan by the present team [16–18, 22–24].

An experimental setup and comprehensive procedure are presented to enhance the quality of raw and processed SPIV data which are required for future turbulence studies. The targets of this procedure, as part of the contribution in this article, are explained in the following items.
SPIV of turbomachines in a region that includes the rotor and the stator blades is a challenging procedure. The adopted region in the present measurements has optical obstructions that may not be removed by changing the imaging direction. A major task that is necessary for any future turbulence analysis is the detection of blade location from appropriate images. PIV does not distinguish between the solid and fluid zones in the images and therefore the exact location of the rotor boundary should be determined by an image processing technique. The review of previous studies shows that most SPIV measurements inside the blades are in particular regions that light obstruction due to the blades is minimum [25–27]. Of course, this condition imposes limitations in the imaging direction and needs a large blade-to-blade distance to decrease the light obstruction due to the blades. Uzol et al. [28] constructed a setup using transparent blades with the same optical index of refraction as the working fluid in order to minimize this obstruction. A deficiency in these studies is that the blade location is determined either visually or by applying a mask over the measured velocity field. In the case of 2C-PIV, this process is reliable because the vector map is extracted from one image. However, SPIV combines the extracted vector maps from two aligned images and the precise location of a specific point in the final map depends on the configuration of the cameras.
Another important issue is the calculation of a vector field from a combination of some overlapping SPIV field of views (FOVs). In SPIV multi-FOV approach, the calibration target is not used to determine the relative location between various FOVs. The experiments for each FOV are independent from the others and, therefore, it is only possible to approximately place the extracted vector map of each FOV beside the map of another overlapping FOV. We devised an algorithm that uses the rotor position and velocity field to obtain the exact location of FOVs.
A correct procedure for phase stamping of the initial data guarantees correct analysis of turbulence characteristics in the future. The available procedures for phase stamping of the PIV data are encoder stamping or defining a time window for data recording. Both procedures are common, but here we select the latter and show the selection and test of a correct window. This procedure is important for a turbomachine with small blade-to-blade distance and required for identifying the phase-matched raw images of a stationary field. Also, the resulting blade tip coordinates help the investigation of jet–wake phenomena downstream of the rotor.

The details of SPIV measurement are described in sections 2 and 3. Section 4 presents the data processing, error analysis of SPIV measurements, and an evaluation of the obtained data. The final part of the article is devoted to the analysis of flow field at the rotor exit.

sec.title: 2.1 Centrifugal fan facility
sec.p:
A forward-curved blade centrifugal fan was constructed to investigate the rotor exit flow field inside a vaneless volute. Figure 1 illustrates a schematic of the centrifugal fan and its components. A 2 kW, three-phase electro-motor is directly coupled to the rotor shaft and turns it at approximately 750 r/min in off-load condition. The electro-motor is installed on a wooden foundation to dampen any vibration. Construction of the side walls and upper section of the volute by the Plexiglas provides the optical access to test section. The rotor is made from a galvanized plate and coated with anti-refractive opaque black spray. Fig. 1
Schematic of the squirrel-cage fan

Dimensions of the rotor, the volute, and the inlet of the centrifugal fan are selected from previous optimization studies [13, 22–24]. Table 1 presents the main geometrical dimensions. Table 1
Geometrical dimensions of the squirrel-cage fan and flow operating conditions at BEP
Rotor Volute
Inner diameter, D1 285 mm Volute width, B 200 mm
Outer diameter, D2 350 mm Outlet height, h 200 mm
Number of blades, N 43 Cut-off radius, r0 210 mm
Blade entrance angle, β1 90° Cut-off angle, γ 60°
Blade exit angle, β1 155° Scroll spread angle, α 5°
Rotor width, b 165 mm Rotor cut-off gap, Sz 35 mm
Exit channel Inlet
Channel length 2750 mm Inner diameter, d1 295 mm
Channel diameter 240 mm Outer diameter, d2 305 mm
Straightener length 480 mm Curvature radius, rI 15 mm
Flow conditions at BEP
Flow coefficient, φr 0.47 Discharge flowrate, Qd 0.62 m3/s
Pressure coefficient, Ψt 2.23 Pressure rise, pFB 110 Pa
Reynolds number, ReD2 3.18 × 105 Rotational speed, n ∼745 r/min

sec.title: 2.2 Performance tests
sec.p: There are many complications in the flow field of a squirrel-cage fan. This includes the inlet-induced separation, jet, and wake structures downstream the rotor, uneven flow distribution around the rotor and returned flow from the volute into the rotor. All these changes at different operating conditions. In this study, it is intended to collect experimental data from the jet and wake flow patterns, sufficiently far from the separation or recirculation zones. The performance test is according to ISO 5801 [29]. The ‘free inlet–ducted outlet’ configuration is applicable to most household and industrial applications and therefore selected for this study. Based on the standard ISO 5801, the exit channel consists of a circular pipe with a star straightener. The dimensions of the PVC duct are presented in Table 1. A static-pitot tube is used to measure pressure and flowrate at various conditions.
The Reynolds number of fan based on the rotor outer-diameter (D2) and peripheral rotor velocity (Utip) is selected to be 3.18 × 105, such that fan performance is independent of Reynolds number [13].

Figure 2 shows the performance curves for the present setup. The non-dimensional quantities φr=4Qv/π2nD2 3 and ψ=2pF/ρπ2n2D2 2 are radial flowrate and pressure coefficients, respectively. Qv is the volumetric flowrate, n the rotational speed of the rotor, and pF the pressure rise. The indices ‘s’ and ‘t’ in Fig. 2 indicate static and total pressures, respectively. According to the performance tests, fan operating condition is selected close to best efficiency point (BEP) for PIV experiments. The BEP flow characteristics are presented in Table 1. Fig. 2
Performance test curves: the operating condition is selected at the BEP, illustrated by diamond symbols

sec.title: 3 PARTICLE IMAGE VELOCIMETRY
sec.p: The 3C-PIV setup consists of a double-cavity Quantel Brilliant Nd-YAG laser. It has 532 nm wave length and 150 mJ/pulse energy and is capable of generating a pair of laser beams with a frequency range of 4–10 Hz. Delivery of laser light to the test section is through a periscope-type optical system. The end part of this device converts the laser light to an illuminating sheet with adjustable thickness (up to 4 mm) and divergence angle about 27 degrees. A compromise between a thicker or a thinner light sheet is necessary. A thicker light sheet reduces the probability of loss-of-pairs, whereas a narrower increases the light intensity. The thickness of laser light sheet is compromised to be about 4 mm.

Dantec FlowMap® system hub synchronizes laser pulses with camera shutters. The time between laser pulses is selected such that the maximum seed displacement between two pulses is about one-fourth of the interrogation area size. This reduces the probability of loss-of-pairs in cross-correlation [30]. The maximum velocity at the rotor exit is expected to be about 35 m/s [31]. The corresponding time step between laser pulses is calculated to be 20 μs. During this period, the rotor rotates about 0.09°, which is approximately 1.1 per cent of the blade-to-blade passage angle. The capacity of system hub memory was limited in transferring the acquired images to the computer; hence, measurements of each FOV are performed in 16 setups (each contains 150 pair of images).

A critical aspect of a successful PIV measurement is seeding uniformity and sufficiency of its concentration within the measurement area. Seeding particles are produced by the evaporation of SAFEX standard fog fluid with a relative specific gravity of 1.17. According to the specifications of SAFEX F2010pluse fog generator, the mean diameter of generated seeds is 1 μm. Each particle should illuminate 2–3 pixels in the charge-coupled device (CCD) plane to provide the optimal particle tracking [32]. According to the camera specifications and the mean diameter of seeds, the particle image diameter in our experiments was approximately twice the image pixel pitch. Therefore, the seeding material used in the experiments is appropriate for PIV measurement in the present setup.

Uniform seeding dispersion with adequate concentration has a significant effect on the measured velocity field. For an open experimental setup, the preparation of this condition is very difficult and time-consuming. In the present setup, the optimum seeding configuration for each FOV is obtained by repeating the experiments with various seeding rates and fog generator positions. Figure 3 illustrates a schematic view of the experimental facility. Fig. 3
Schematic illustration of experimental setup
Two FlowSense® 1600 × 1186 pixel cross-correlation CCD cameras with AF Micro Nikkor® lenses and 532 nm optical high-pass filter record the images.
The angular displacement configuration with two cameras is employed to capture two pairs of images from the test section for stereoscopic imaging.

The complicated flow pattern at the outer region of turbomachine rotor increases the importance of employing accurate phase-matched data in the ensemble-averaging calculations. The frequency of laser pulse is not fixed during the experiments and changes with the fluctuations in rotor speed. Although selection of a time window for phase-matched data is a normal procedure (like the one in FlowManager©), an incremental encoder ensures a trigger as close as possible to the target angular phase.

sec.title: 3.1 Selection of the measurement area
sec.p:
The flow field downstream of the rotor blades of a squirrel-cage fan contains signatures from the inlet velocity profile, turning flow into the rotor, and flow through the blades. It is also the contributor for the rotating flow inside the volute. The rotor exit flow is highly vortical in the first one-third axial region (from the inlet shroud) and the prominent jet–wake structures are at the remaining two-third axial zone [13, 16, 17]. Previous studies on squirrel-cage fans have indicated significant interactions between jets and wakes in the upper region of rotor exit (close to volute outlet) [23]. It is concluded that the flow field at rotor exit, near the fan outlet, and towards the rotor back-plate can characterize the flow out of the rotor of a centrifugal turbomachine and its investigation has applications in other similar turbomachines. It also identifies the sources of turbomachine deficiencies and improves the modelling capabilities for more accurate flow predictions. A measurement plane perpendicular to the rotor axis is desirable to study the jet–wake structures. For this study, a section at z/B=0.6 (z is measured from the rotor inlet) and at the upper region of rotor is selected (Fig. 4). Fig. 4
Position and dimension of measuring FOVs 1–4

The smallest resolvable velocity structure, λs, should be considered to determine the dimensions of the measurement area. According to the study of Saarenrinne et al. [33], setting the value of λs in the range 20-90η (η indicates the Kolmogorov length scale) covers 65–95 per cent of turbulent kinetic energy. Although it is always desirable to study the smallest structures in the flow field, the purpose of this research is to investigate the jet–wake phenomena which requires an area with sufficiently large dimensions that includes a number of jets and wakes. The order of magnitude of the Kolmogorov length scale can be calculated from η~l Rel -3/4=(ν3l/u3)1/4. For the present measurements, the velocity scale is adopted as the characteristic turbulent fluctuation velocity, u≈2 m/s, and the blade-to-blade distance is selected as the mean flow length scale, l≈2.6 cm. Based on these values, the order of magnitude of Kolmogorov length scale is estimated as 57 μm. The smallest resolvable velocity structure is set as 37η. Determination of camera magnification factor requires knowledge of the size of the interrogation area (in pixel) and pixel pitch of the camera CCD. The camera magnification factor is 0.118, based on 32 × 32 pixel interrogation area and 7.4 μm pixel pitch. Finally, the dimension of FOV is based on these known parameters and the camera resolution and calculated to be 100×74 mm2. The optimum camera f-number is calculated and set to 11 [34]. Four adjacent FOVs are selected with shared boundaries to cover a larger measurement area.

sec.title: 3.2 Measurement uncertainties
sec.p: PIV measurement uncertainties can be classified into random and bias errors. Random errors correspond to unsystematic measuring features and are difficult to evaluate. A large enough number of experiments balances such errors and provides reliable averages. Bias errors are predictable and relate to systematic aspects of measurement. The reduction of random errors often requires performing the experiments more accurately, while decreasing bias errors requires specific approaches to different features of PIV measurement and analysis. The most important bias errors of SPIV measurements are errors due to particle lag effect, light refraction, stereoscopic image capturing, and displacement estimation.

A source of error is the lag due to the difference between fluid and particle specific gravities. The expected tracking error can be calculated from reference [35] (1) Δu is the deviation of particle velocity from the fluid velocity, ν=1.5×10-5 m2/s is kinematic viscosity, and ω0 the lowest turn over frequency of large eddies. For the large eddies with a velocity scale in the order of blade tip velocity and a length scale in the order of blade-to-blade distance, ω0 is calculated to be about 700 Hz. The other known parameters are ρp/ρf=1.17 and dp=1 μm. Substituting these values into equation (1), the expected tracking error due to particle lag effect is about 0.015 per cent. Even if the blade thickness is used in the calculation of ω0, the error is about 0.07 per cent.

The transparent window between the measurement area and the cameras refracts light and may cause errors. Refractive errors increase with window thickness and the angle of incident light. The camera calibration is performed in the presence of the window and refraction errors are therefore covered [25].

The uncertainty in inclined image capturing of an angular configuration is estimated from the theoretical results of error analysis by Lawson and Wu [36]. The ratio of out-of-plane error to in-plane error (es) is calculated based on [36] both symmetric and non-symmetric configurations and illustrated in Fig. 5 (d0 is the normal distance between FOV and the camera lens and x is measured in the FOV plane with respect to its centre). It should be noticed that a larger off-axis angle reduces the overlap area between the images. Fig. 5
Out-of-plane to in-plane error ratio in symmetrical and non-symmetrical configurations

Comparison between symmetric and non-symmetric configurations shows that symmetrically setting up the cameras results in a more accurate measurement. However, the deficiency of non-symmetric configuration can be improved by a higher off-axis angle for the inclined camera. In this experimental setup, optical obstructions prevented us from applying the symmetric configuration. A non-symmetric configuration, in which one camera is perpendicular to the measurement plane, is considered for stereoscopic imaging (Fig. 6). This allows maximum possible access to the FOVs. After an initial error analysis, the angle between cameras is set to 30°. According to Fig. 5, the corresponding error ratio (out-of-plane error to in-plane error) for a 30° off-axis angle in non-symmetric configuration is about 2–3. This means that the normal displacement estimation error is up to three times that of the in-plane displacement. Fig. 6
Non-symmetrical configuration of cameras in stereoscopic imaging
Although the inclined imaging in an angular displacement configuration has the drawback that the focus would be non-uniform, the Scheimpflug condition eliminates this problem [37].

The estimation error of correlation peak position without employing the interpolation techniques in image processing is of the order of 1 pixel, while by applying the interpolation, the accuracy of extracting correlation peak position reduces to sub-pixel values. The nominal error in the estimation of correlation peak position by Gaussian peak fit has been evaluated in the order of 0.1 pixel [32]. For a 32×32 pixel interrogation area with the one-fourth displacement rule, the error in displacement estimation is about 0.1/8≈1.25 per cent.

The overall bias error is the sum of various bias errors in the worst condition, which, based on the above calculations, is lower than 1.5 per cent for the in-plane velocity component. For out-of-plane velocity component, the upper limit of bias error is about 4 per cent.

sec.title: 4 DATA PROCESSING
sec.p: FlowManager software (version 4.6) [38] is used to extract the velocity components from the raw images. The processes include imaging calibration and process of raw images, data validation, and a combination of two-dimensional (2D) velocity vector maps.

Calibration of cameras builds the geometrical relationships required for the reconstruction of velocity vectors from two separate 2D vector maps. The calibration images are captured from a single-sided calibration target. The reconstruction mapping is obtained by FlowManager software and a third-order XYZ-polynomial method [38].

The raw velocity vector maps are drawn after applying multi-stage adaptive cross-correlation. Initial cross-correlation process is over a 128 × 128 pixel interrogation window and after two stages of adaptive correlation, the vector maps are extracted for 32 × 32 pixel areas. Horizontal and vertical overlaps between interrogation areas are selected to be 50 per cent. Data validation procedure, which includes velocity-range, peak-height, and moving-average validations eliminates or substitutes spurious velocity vectors. To obtain the 3C-velocity field, each pair of resulting 2D vector maps are combined based on the calibration mapping model.
The phase-averaged velocity components and vorticity (normal to the measurement area) are calculated from (2) (3)

Superscript (n) corresponds to various phase-matched samples and indices 1–3 indicate orthogonal directions x, y, and z, respectively (illustrated in Fig. 1). The symbol á·ñ indicates phase-averaging. In single-plane SPIV measurements, only the normal component of vorticity (ω3) may be calculated.

sec.title: 4.1 Exact determination of rotor location
sec.p:
The metallic rotor of the present fan limits the optical access to its outer region. Therefore, the extracted velocity vector maps at the regions of FOVs 1 and 2 which are located inside the rotor are not valid and have to be masked. Figure 7 illustrates an instantaneous image corresponding to FOV 1. The arc-shaped dark region at the lower left side of the image is part of the rotor back plate. Image processing is carried out on the normal camera images to detect the outer margin of the rotor. The computational code for image processing is based on the pixel light intensity of greyscale images [39]. Fig. 7
An instantaneous image corresponding to FOV 1

The procedure for detection of the outer margin of the rotor at FOVs 1 and 2 is as follows.
A new picture is formed by averaging the light intensity of each pixel over all the images of a setup. Since the position of the rotor relative to the normal camera is fixed, averaging reduces the local noise and a comparison between interrogation areas (step 3) is more reliable.
The images are divided into an p×q array of overlapping interrogation areas, each with adjustable dimension of m×n pixels, and smoothing is performed in each interrogation area, by averaging the light intensity over that area.
In each column set of interrogation areas, the averaged value of light intensity is compared for adjacent areas and the location of maximum difference is considered as a point on the outer boundary of the rotor.
The rotor boundary is a circular arc fit to the points of step 3 since rotor back plate is circular and the camera has a normal view relative to back plate. The centre coordinate (xc,yc) and radius (R r) of the fitted arc are determined when the residue δ in the following relation is minimum
(4)
In this relation, the number of FOVs is indicated by index i and xe and ye are the rotor boundary coordinates (obtained in step 3).

The shining spots over the rotor rim in the images (Fig. 7) are reflections of laser beam from metal blade tips. The following procedures are carried out on the images from the normal camera to detect blade tip positions and select phase-matched images.
Images are divided into overlapping interrogation areas and light intensities are smoothed over each area.
The interrogation areas in the neighbourhood of the outer margin of the rotor are investigated and by comparison of light intensity in the adjacent areas, the locations of local maximums are found. These locations are markedly brighter than seed signatures, occupy a considerably larger number of pixels, and are considered as the position of blade tips.
An investigation of a large number of images showed that in each image, there is at least one shining spot. Hence, the location of the highest light intensity in the previous step is selected as the position of a blade tip. The positions of other blade tips are determined from the knowledge of the number of blades and the outer margin of the rotor.
The length of the angular window is selected to be 1°, which is determined by an investigation of the histogram of blade tip locations with respect to angular position. The best range is the one that contains a larger number of blade tips.

sec.title: 4.2 Exact determination of FOV location
sec.p: The initial setup of a PIV system includes laser light sheet and camera positioning. The cameras cover the desired FOV but with undefined boundaries. In stereoscopic PIV, the images are combined according to a calibration model fit to give a 3C-velocity vector map. It is not possible to combine velocity components in the non-overlapped area of the two image pairs. Therefore, the combined image map in each FOV is smaller than each of the initial image pairs. When the measurement area consists of two or more FOVs, an algorithm should accurately find the relative position of the resulting images. This is devised in a way that starts from an initial approximate positioning and then searches for the exact relative location of FOVs.

The experiments of this study are performed on four overlapping FOVs where two of them cover regions of the rotor (FOVs 1 and 2). The exact location of rotor included FOVs can be determined after the detection of blade tip locations (section 4.1).

The correct location of the two remaining FOVs (FOVs 3 and 4) are obtained by mutual comparison of velocity vector maps for each pair of FOVs (namely FOV 3 with FOV 1 and FOV 4 with FOV 2). Since the snapshots of each pair of FOVs are not concurrent, the comparison is based on ensemble-averaged velocities. The procedure for determining the exact location of one FOV (slave) with respect to the other one (master) is as follows.
Calculation of the map of ensemble-averaged velocity magnitude (V¯) from the following equation
(5)
Displacement of the slave FOV with respect to the master FOV and determination of the overlapping region.
Calculation of the norm of velocity difference for corresponding nodes, over the overlapping region; this is calculated from
(6) where (xd ,yd ) is the displacement vector for the slave FOV.
Repetition of steps (2) and (3) for various displacement vectors and obtaining a displacement vector for which the norm of velocity difference becomes the minimum.
It is expected that the optimum displacement vector locates the slave FOV in a correct position with respect to the master FOV.

sec.title: 4.3 Evaluation of data processing
sec.p:
Figures 8 and 9 present the combination of velocity and vorticity vector maps of the four FOVs. Figures 8(a) and 9(a) show the initial extracted data from FlowManager, whereas Figs 8(b) and 9(b) show the result of post-processing over such data. The number of initial acquired images (vector maps) is 2400 for each FOV. This is termed the ‘initial extracted data’. The acquisition window is then made smaller until the data quality is acceptable. The remaining realizations are the ‘processed data’. The number of acceptable images for the final analysis is 500–1000 for different FOVs. The illustrated contour plots in Figs 8(b) and 9(b) indicate the phase averages and those in Figs 8(a) and 9(a)of these figures are obtained by averaging over the entire 2400 snapshots. Fig. 8
Velocity contours from a combination of four FOVs: before image enhancement (a) and after image enhancement (b) Fig. 9
Normal vorticity contour from a combination of four FOVs: before image enhancement (a) and after image enhancement (b)

A comparison of Figs 8(a) and (b) and 9(a) and (b) shows the following points.
The mismatch between rotor phases in various images causes inappropriate averaging of initial data. Hence, the jet–wake structures are mixed and the clarity of each pattern is reduced. Figures 8(b) and 9(b) show that separation of phase-matched images has resulted in more distinguishable patterns.
The velocity and vorticity of the processed data at the interface of FOVs are more uniform and continuous because the velocity difference norm of the processed data across the FOVs is minimized.
The vorticity is calculated based on velocity derivatives. Hence, for the mismatched initial data, the vorticity pattern is significantly noisy, as evident in Fig. 9(a). The phase-matched image selection gives more defined patterns in the vorticity map (Fig. 9(b)).
As a consequence of blade tip detection process, the relative behaviour of exit flow patterns with respect to rotor blade orientation is more reliable. For the non-processed data, however, there is no criterion for deciding on rotor blade orientation.

It must be noticed that turbulent quantities such as Reynolds stresses, turbulent kinetic energy, turbulence production, and dissipation are more sensitive to data processing. A mismatch between rotor phases may remove the dominant behaviours in the flow field obtained by ensemble averaging.

sec.title: 4.4 Convergency analysis
sec.p:
The ensemble-averaged quantities must converge in different points of the field in order to demonstrate that the numbers of image pairs are sufficient and ensure a reliable ensemble-averaged field from PIV technique. Six locations are selected to assess the convergency of ensemble averaging in this study (Fig. 10 (locations A–F)). These locations are selected in high-momentum regions (points B and C), wake flows (points A and D), and localized high-vorticity regions (points E and F). Variation of averaged velocity and averaged normal vorticity with the number of images for averaging is illustrated in Fig. 11(a) and (b). The curves correspond to various locations (A–F). The number of employed images in FOVs 1–4 is different, since there are different numbers of phase-matched images in various FOVs. Fig. 10
Locations of convergency evaluation points (A–F), arcs for investigation of circumferential variations of flow quantities, and the curvilinear paths corresponding to high- (white lines) and low-momentum (black lines) flow regions on the contour plots of (a) velocity and (b) normal vorticity Fig. 11
Variation of average velocity (a) and average normal vorticity (b) versus the number of images

Velocity field convergence is achieved from considerably fewer images compared with the vorticity field. The reason is that vorticity is calculated from the spatial derivative of velocity components and consequently more sensitive to any noise in the velocity field.

The effect of the last 100 images on ensemble-averaged quantities is calculated and presented in Tables 2 and 3 to evaluate the convergency of velocity and vorticity in more detail. The average of an ensemble quantity (Aave) is calculated from (7) where A is the ensemble-averaged velocity (V¯) or ensemble-averaged normal vorticity (ωz¯). Maximum deviation of a quantity (velocity or vorticity) is defined as the maximum deviation of ensemble-averaged values for last 100 added samples and the normalized maximum deviation is calculated by dividing the maximum deviation to the average of ensemble quantities over the last 100 samples. Table 2
Statistics of velocity convergence in points A–F
Location Averaged ensemble velocity Maximum deviation Normalized maximum deviation (%) Standard deviation Normalized standard deviation (%)
A 24.42 0.04 0.16 0.02 0.06
B 31.01 0.07 0.23 0.04 0.12
C 29.71 0.02 0.07 0.01 0.04
D 24.65 0.03 0.12 0.02 0.06
E 18.66 0.02 0.12 0.01 0.06
F 20.18 0.02 0.10 0.01 0.05
Table 3
Statistics of normal vorticity convergence in points A–F
Location Averaged ensemble vorticity Maximum deviation Normalized maximum deviation (%) Standard deviation Normalized standard deviation (%)
A −114.62 8.64 7.53 4.16 3.63
B 18.72 8.01 42.79 3.30 17.62
C 115.95 1.93 1.67 1.18 1.01
D 73.53 5.24 7.12 2.06 2.80
E −44.76 2.29 5.11 1.09 2.44
F 159.22 3.67 2.30 1.89 1.18

Moreover, standard deviation of quantities is calculated from (8) and the normalized standard deviation is obtained by dividing SD to the average of ensemble quantities. Normalized standard deviation and normalized maximum deviation in Tables 2 and 3 show that the convergence of ensemble averaging for the velocity field is quite desirable and considerably better than that of the vorticity field. This is true for every location in the FOV (including jets, wakes, and localized vorticity spots).

It was stated that the procedure for phase-matched image selection included an optimum angular window. A large window size averages data from neighbouring angular positions and does not calculate a stationary field. The deviations in ensemble averaging of quantities within this window, particularly for the vorticity field, are more sensitive to noise. Table 3 shows that except for location B, the normalized standard and normalized maximum deviations of vorticity are small for the selected window. A reason for larger values of normalized statistics for vorticity at location B is the smaller value of ensemble-averaged vorticity at this point.

sec.title: 5 FLOW FIELD ANALYSIS
sec.p: The flow field inside the volute of a vaneless centrifugal turbomachine is affected significantly by jet, wake, and volute interactions. The large number of blades (shorter blade-to-blade distance) and the large width-to-diameter ratio of the rotor intensify the interaction between jet and wake structures and make the flow field more complex.

Figure 8(b) shows that the exit flow of the rotor is composed of a combination of jet and wake patterns. In other words, flow with momentum deficit due to blades (black lines in Fig. 10) moves in the vicinity of high-momentum flow regions (white lines in Fig. 10) to generate these mutual structures. As the fluid moves away from the rotor, jet, and wake intensities diminish and their identification and distinction become more difficult. The interaction between high- and low-momentum streams balances the flow towards a more uniform velocity field, away from the blades. The flow along the volute wall, which is formed from the rotor outward streams in the previous angular positions, interacts with these jet–wake structures. Mixing of these flow streams results in the variation of flow characteristics at regions away from the rotor (FOVs 3 and 4). The fluctuations in the averaged-velocity field at FOVs 3 and 4 (Fig. 8(b)) are the consequence of earlier jet and wake signatures in the instantaneous frames and the interaction between jet and wake structures and flow along the volute wall.

The Cartesian components of velocity field are illustrated in Fig. 12(a) to (c) in order to investigate the flow field in different directions. The white and black curves indicate the jet and wake trajectories, respectively. The following remarks result from a comparison of these contour plots.
The x-component of velocity is larger than other components and the flow field is dominantly towards the volute outlet. Moreover, the out-of-plane velocity component has a smaller magnitude in comparison with other in-plane components and therefore the flow field is almost planar in the investigated region. This out-of-plane velocity field may still be effective in contributing to the flow field characteristics. This feature was also observed in the previous studies [13, 16, 17].
The in-plane and out-of-plane velocity components have maximums around jet trajectories whereas minimums around wake trajectories. This behaviour is consistent with the observed behaviour for the velocity magnitude (Fig. 10(a)).
The x-component of velocity is dominant in the region around the FOV 1, whereas the dominancy of y-component of velocity is towards the left region of the FOV 2. This characteristic is consistent with the geometry of centrifugal fan. It is expected that the gross flow field around FOV 1 is towards the volute outlet, while around FOV 2, the flow tends to move, both horizontally and vertically.
The circumferential distribution of the out-of-plane velocity component around the rotor exit is uniform in comparison with the in-plane velocity components. In other words, the peaks and valleys of the out-of-plane velocity component regularly repeat around the rotor. The entrance flow of the fan that is mainly in the axial direction is the main contributor of the out-of-plane velocity component in the rotor exit region. Because of internal symmetry of the rotor relative to the inlet, the regularity of z-component of velocity in the circumferential direction is more than the regularity of other in-plane components.
Some localized regions with small out-of-plane velocities are evident in the contour plot of out-of-plane velocity component in FOVs 3 and 4. This periodic spotwise pattern may be due to streamwise vortices, generated due to interaction between the volute flow from previous circumferential locations and jet–wake structures. More precise study of vortex evolution requires the temporal-spatial analysis of flow field based on high-frequency measurements.
Fig. 12
Normalized velocity components in the Cartesian coordinate system; x-component (a), y-component (b), and z-component (c)

Figure 13 shows the radial and tangential velocity components in the measured area. Some useful points from the analysis of these contour plots are given as follows.
Integration of the radial velocity component over the rotor outlet gives the flow out flux from the rotor. Investigation of the radial velocity component in Fig. 13(a) shows that the out flux becomes larger in the regions closer to the volute outlet.
Low values for the radial velocity component around FOV 4 compared with the moderate values of the tangential component indicate that the flow field is mainly tangential in this region. In fact, the volute effectively characterizes the flow and turns the flow towards the volute outlet.
Fig. 13
Normalized velocity components in the polar coordinate system: radial component (a) and tangential component (b)

The variation of normalized velocity over arcs at different distances away from the rotor (Fig. 10) is presented in Fig. 14(a). Jet–wake directions are not radial (Fig. 10) and therefore in order to demonstrate a general pattern among various arcs, they are matched in Fig. 14(b) by rotating the curve of each arc with respect to the curve of the inner arc (located at r/R=1.035). The local velocity maximum of each curve (indicating the centre of jets) is identified and used to determine the required angle of rotation that matches jet structures in radial directions. The rotation over each curve is the average required rotation angle for various jets on that curve. Patterns show a repeatable structure over different arcs. The reason for any mismatch in FOV 2 may be explained from Fig. 10(a). Although the direction of jet–wake structures in both FOVs is almost straight and towards the discharge duct of the fan, they have different levels of interaction with the volute flow. Fig. 14
Variation of average velocity with circumferential position over various arcs: before angular displacement of arcs (a) and after displacing the arcs (b)

A notable aspect in Fig. 10(b) is the location of jet trajectories relative to blade tips. The jets tend towards the suction sides of the rotor blades more than their pressure sides. This was also reported in hotwire measurements of Suárez et al. [15] inside a forward-curved centrifugal fan. Although they studied the temporal variations of velocity field at fixed locations, a comparison of the results of this study with their measurements is informative. Figure 15 shows the variation of normalized tangential velocity on a blade pitch (blade-to-blade distance for this study and passing time interval between two adjacent blades for the study of Suárez et al.). Both curves correspond to r/R=1.05, but the hotwire measurements were at the circumferential location of 270° and z/B=0.5, while the PIV results are at z/B=0.6 and for the spatial range 1.5–10°, approximately. Furthermore, the geometrical specification and operating condition of fans are different. Nevertheless, Fig. 15 shows a general agreement between unsteady measurements of Suárez et al. and present PIV measurements. Fig. 15
Comparison between unsteady measurements of Suárez et al. [15] and present PIV measurements within one blade pitch

An investigation of the vorticity field indicates further complexities in the flow field at the outlet of rotor blades of the centrifugal turbomachine (Fig. 9(b)). The jet and wake trajectories of Fig. 10(a) are overlaid in Fig. 10(b). Figures 9(b) and 10(b) show regular patterns of phase-averaged vorticity with opposite signs along the trailing edge of the blades. A pair of intensive vorticity layers with opposite values is generated on different sides of each wake trajectory. Similar patterns have been observed in the experimental studies on the axial and centrifugal pumps, downstream of rotor and stator blades [10]. The large value of vorticity on the near-boundary regions of wake structures is due to the interaction between high- and low-momentum flows, along the pressure and suction sides of the blades. As the fluid flows away from the rotor, these interactions diminish and the vorticity magnitude in the jet–wake structures drops.

It was stated in this section that the interaction between mainstream along the volute and the jet–wake structures creates a complicated and non-uniform flow field in FOVs 3 and 4. The flow along the volute wall is a collection of jets and wakes at the narrower regions of volute and is consequently non-uniform and turbulent. Interaction of wake–wake structures creates distinct vorticity spots in the flow field that are distinguishable in Fig. 9(b). Chow et al. [5] obtained similar isolated vorticity spots as a result of the interaction between rotor and stator wakes, in an axial turbomachine. Analysis of these localized spots showed that these regions contain vortical structures with elevated turbulence levels. Such structures interact with stationary flow structures in different turbomachines (due to stator blades or vaned diffusers) and create discontinuities in the stator wake trajectories. In this study, these discontinuities are recognizable in Fig. 9(b) (localized positive and negative vorticity spots). It was observed earlier that the flow field along the volute wall is non-uniform. A comparison between Figs 8(b) and 9(b) indicates that generation of discontinuous turbulent structures across the volute flow can be the result of the wake–wake interaction.

Figure 16(a) shows the variation of normalized vorticity over various arcs, from r/R=1.06 to r/R=1.56. The direction of jet–wake trajectories deviates from the radial lines through the centre of rotor. Vorticity patterns of each curve are turned to match the jet–wake structures of various curves (Fig. 16(b)). The positive and negative peaks of vorticity (which occur at both sides of wakes) are more intensive in the vicinity of rotor outlet. As the fluid moves away from the rotor, the intensity of vorticity peaks diminishes but the relative prominence of jet–wake structures in FOV 1 increases with respect to FOV 2. Similar to velocity patterns (Fig. 14(b)), the vorticity patterns in FOV 2 are not well-matched and incline towards the volute outlet, as the fluid moves downstream of the rotor. Fig. 16
Variation of average normal vorticity with circumferential position over various arcs: before angular displacement of arcs (a) and after displacing the arcs (b)

Figure 16(b) shows the regular oscillations of vorticity around zero. The reason for these opposite patterns is jet–wake and wake–jet interactions. In other words, interaction of each wake structure with jet structures on both sides of the blade creates opposite patterns of vorticity. These patterns are almost symmetric around the zero vorticity for each wake trajectory, particularly in FOV 1. Fig. 17
Contour plot of relative velocity with relative frame streamlines (a) and absolute frame streamlines (b)

Figure 17(a) shows the normalized relative velocity contours and their corresponding streamlines. The momentum deficit due to rotor blades is apparent in the wake regions. Although velocity patterns in the rotational and stationary frames of reference are similar, streamlines of relative and absolute velocities are completely different (Figs 17(a) and (b)). Figure 17(a) shows discharge flow from the trailing edge of blades has a good blade congruency. A noticeable matter that can be seen in the relative velocity streamlines is the regular and roughly straight relative flow trajectories, even far from the rotor (FOVs 3 and 4). It is expected that away from the rotor blades, tangential component of velocity diminishes and relative velocity stream traces incline towards the volute wall. However, as mentioned before, the interaction between the fluid flow along the volute wall and the discharged flow from the rotor directs the absolute velocity streamlines towards the volute outlet (Fig. 17(b)) and increases the tangential component of velocity.

sec.title: 6 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p:
SPIV is applied to the flow field in the rotor exit of a forward-curved multi-blade centrifugal fan. The experimental considerations, error analysis, and the procedure for phase-matching of images are presented in detail and the flow patterns investigated. The main concluding remarks of this study are given as follows.
Optical obstructions, non-uniform distribution of seeds, and the dependency of flow field on the blade position are the features that make PIV measurements of turbomachinery flow more challenging than that of simple flow fields.
The overall bias error of in-plane SPIV measurements is estimated to be less than 1.5 per cent and that for out-of-plane velocity estimation is at most 4 per cent.
In a turbomachine with large number of blades, such as squirrel-cage fan, PIV measurement is very sensitive to phase-matching of the acquired images. Processing of non-matched data and identifying the phase-matched images clearly reveal the flow patterns at rotor exit. Without these processes, the extracted ensemble-averaged velocity field was noisy and had an undesirable effect on the velocity-derived quantities such as vorticity.
The interaction between jet and wake structures in the rotor exit region is an important contributor to the complex flow field of multi-blade centrifugal fan. Layers with high absolute vorticity on the near-boundary regions of wake structures are expected to be the result of interaction between high- and low-momentum streams.
Advection of jet–wake layers downstream of the rotor and their interaction with the flow along the volute wall (that is collected from previous jet–wake structures) create non-uniformities in the velocity field and its derived quantities. Another consequence of these interactions is the inclination of jet–wake trajectories towards the volute outlet.

Despite flow complexities in multi-blade centrifugal turbomachines, their flow patterns consist of regular characteristics. Gaining sufficient knowledge about these flow characteristics is the first stage in development of turbulence models and improvement of fluid flow simulations in these complicated geometries.

The next stage will be more extended turbulence analysis on the results of this article. This includes the study of energy cascade and backscattering of energy, evaluation of common models, and employing statistical methods to parameterize turbulent flow quantities. Such studies, which are certainly novel in centrifugal turbomachinery, require detailed experimental setup and comprehensive data management. In fact, the validity of any such analysis in 3D would strongly depend on the initial data collection and process. Our contributions in the process of blade detection, selection of phase-resolved images, and combination of different FOVs in this article are quite necessary for the future studies.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: The present research was supported and funded by research grants of ‘Amirkabir University of Technology’.
